Title: $\Bbb{Q}$ is not a finitely generated $\Bbb{Z}$-module
Content: I'm trying to show that $\Bbb{Q}$ is not a finitely generated $\Bbb{Z}$-module. Assume to the contrary that $$\Bbb{Q}=\Bbb{Z}\dfrac{a_1}{b_1}+...+\Bbb{Z}\dfrac{a_n}{b_n}$$ where $a_i,b_i\in\Bbb{Z}$. Let lcm$(b_1,...,b_n)=c$ and $d_i=\dfrac{c}{b_i}$. Then $$\Bbb{Q}=\dfrac{d_1a_1}{c}\Bbb{Z}+...+\dfrac{d_na_n}{c}\Bbb{Z}$$ Now let $p$ be a prime that does not divide $c$. Then, there are $x_1,...,x_n\in\Bbb{Z}$ such that $$\dfrac{1}{p}=\dfrac{d_1a_1x_1+...+d_na_nx_n}{c}$$ and hence $p(d_1a_1x_1+...+d_na_nx_n)=c$, which means that $p$ divides $c$, contradiction. That was suspiciously easy. What am I missing?
AcceptedAnswer: It is in fact that easy. You can make it even simpler by noting you can conclude $\mathbb Q \subseteq \langle \frac{1}{c} \rangle$ from your assumption. Since $\frac{1}{2c}\in\mathbb Q$ we have $\frac{1}{2c}=\frac{k}{c}$ for some $k\in\mathbb Z$, but there is no $k\in\mathbb Z$ such that $2k=1$.
